Zip_Code.title: Zip Code
Zip_Code.content: Enter the zip code for your project location. Our database automatically populates the design Wind Speed and Ground Snow Loads associated with your project location, as determined by ASCE 7-10. These values can be confirmed by consulting your local building authority.

Wind_Exposure.title: Wind Exposure Categories
Wind_Exposure.content:
Exposure B: 
Urban and suburban areas, wooded areas, or other terrain with numerous closely spaced obstructions having the size of single family dwellings or larger.

Exposure C:
Open terrain with scattered obstructions having heights generally less than 30 feet. This category includes flat open country and grasslands.

Exposure D:  
Flat, unobstructed areas and water surfaces. This category includes smooth mud flats, salt flats, and unbroken ice.

*Wind Exposure Category can be confirmed by consulting your local building authority.

Risk_Category_pitched.title: Risk Category
Risk_Category_pitched.content:
Solar array support systems (like IronRidge) are designed using Risk Category I (this is the same as Occupancy Category I' from ASCE 7-05). Risk Category I refers to, 'buildings or other structures with a low hazard to human life in the event of failure.

Solar arrays are considered Risk Category I because they are only cladding upon an existing structure, and the structural failure of the solar array is considered to have 'low hazard to human life

If you are attempting to calculate the impact of the solar array on the building structure, you should consult a structural engineer. These types of calculations are beyond the capability of Design Assistant

Risk_Category_flat.title: Risk Category
Risk_Category_flat.content:
Projects designed using the Flat Roof Design Assistant comply with ASCE 7-10 Risk Category II loads (equivalent to ASCE 7-05 Occupancy Category II loads) resulting in the Tilt Mount System having the same structural integrity and reliability as the building it is deployed on (typically Risk Category II per ASCE 7-10 Table 1.5-1; or ASCE 705 Table 1-1).

The higher risk category is adopted for the Tilt Mount System compared to the Flush Mount system due to our engineering judgement and the evolving consensus of the industry that the nature of commercial buildings merit the higher Category II loadings.

Wind_Speed.title: Wind Speed
Wind_Speed.content: Design Wind Speed for your project location as determined by ASCE 7-10. These values can be confirmed by consulting your local building authority.

Ground_Snow_Load.title: Ground Snow Load
Ground_Snow_Load.content: Design Ground Snow Load for your project location as determined by ASCE 7-10. These values can be confirmed by consulting your local building authority.

Attachment_Spacing.title: Attachment Spacing
Attachment_Spacing.content:
The distance between roof attachments. This number should be less than or equal to the maximum span value listed for your selected XR Rail within the 'Rails' section.

Typical residential installations have attachment spacing between 4' and 8', whereas commercial installations have spacing as high as 12'. Consult with a structural engineer or your local building authority to confirm the allowable attachment spacing for your array.

flashfoot.title: FlashFoot
flashfoot.content: IronRidge FlashFoot is an all-in-one flashing and attachment product for composition shingle roofs. By selecting FlashFoot, Design Assistant automatically removes standoffs and L-feet from your bill of materials and factors-in the FlashFoot's loading capabilities into the Engineering Validation section.

flashfoot2.title: FlashFoot2
flashfoot2.content:
IronRidge FlashFoot2 is an all-in-one flashing and attachment product for composition shingle roofs, and has been completely redesigned with a seal that is both elevated and fully encapsulated. Selecting FlashFoot2 will automatically remove standoffs and L-feet from your bill of materials – and will factor in FlashFoot2’s loading capacities* into the Reaction Forces.

*Capacities are based on a substrate with a specific gravity of 0.54.

attachment_bonding_hardware.title: Attachment Bonding Hardware
attachment_bonding_hardware.content: Attachment bonding hardware now comes in both square bolt and t-bolt options in order to accommodate installer preference. Selecting either option will automatically add bonding hardware to your bill of materials, and will calculate the quantity needed to support your project.

Rails.title: The XR Rail Family
Rails.content:
XR Rails are the backbone of the solar array. All three options feature IronRidge’s signature curved profile, providing both an attractive appearance and increased performance.

Each XR Rail size supports specific design loads and max spans, while minimizing material costs.

Select between the different XR Rail options to see the impact on project cost.

Max_Span.title: Max Span
Max_Span.content: Max allowable spacing between attachment points, based on engineered span charts.

Max_Cantilever.title: Max Cantilever
Max_Cantilever.content: Max Cantilever is calculated as 0.40 x maximum span from engineered span charts

Engineering.title: Reaction Force per Attachment
Engineering.content: The engineering information below is calculated based on the Load Conditions and Building Details. The values represent max reaction forces per attachment. A max reaction force will turn red if it exceeds the capability of your selected attachment.

Down.title: Max Downforce at Attachment (lbs)
Down.content:
Maximum compression, perpendicular to the roof slope, acting on a roof at the point of attachment due to the portion of snow load, wind load, module weights and racking weights supported by a specific attachment.

If the Attachment Spacing is reduced to a value smaller than the Max Span, then this value will be scaled down proportionally.

Uplift.title: Max Uplift at Attachment (lbs)
Uplift.content:
Maximum tension, perpendicular to the roof slope, acting on a roof at the point of attachment due to the portion of wind load supported by a specific attachment.

If the Attachment Spacing is reduced to a value smaller than the Max Span, then this value will be scaled down proportionally.

Lateral.title: Lateral Reaction at Attachment (lbs)
Lateral.content:
Average force, parallel to the roof slope, acting on a roof attachment due to the snow load, module weights and racking weights.

If the Attachment Spacing is reduced to a value smaller than the Max Span, then this value will be scaled down proportionally.

Microinverter_Kits.title: Microinverter Kits
Microinverter_Kits.content:
If you will be using micro inverters, IronRidge can provide microinverter kits for mounting them to our rails.

Each kit includes 1/4' bolts and associated hardware. Design Assistant will add one kit for every two modules to the bill of materials (one bolt per micro inverter).

Wire_Clips.title: Wire Clips
Wire_Clips.content: Wire Clips provide a quick and easy way to manage PV cables. Simply click into the top rail slot, insert wires and lock shut.

End_Caps.title: End Caps
End_Caps.content: End Caps easily snap into the ends of the rails, providing a finished look and keeping the inside of the rail free of dirt, debris and insects.

Required_Rail.title: Required Rail
Required_Rail.content: The exact length of rail required to fully support the specified number of modules in each row.

Provided_Rail.title: Provided Rail
Provided_Rail.content: Design Assistant automatically takes into consideration the available rail lengths and recommends the optimal lengths for each row, based on minimizing the amount of extra rail.

Attach_Pts.title: Provided Rail
Attach_Pts.content: The number of attachments required based on the attachment spacing that was entered on the Design tab. The larger the attachment spacing, the fewer the number of required attachments.

columns.title: Subarray Columns
columns.content: To avoid potential problems caused by the effects of thermal expansion, a maximum total continuous cross pipe length of 100 feet is recommended. If you plan to exceed 100 feet, please consult a structural engineer.

area.title: Area
area.content: This represents the dimensions of the array table, and does not include inter-row spacing.

tilt_Angle.title: Tilt Angle
tilt_Angle.content: Select the tilt of the array relative to level ground (the horizontal axis).

pipe_Tubing_Size.title: Pipe or Mechanical Tubing Size
pipe_Tubing_Size.content:
Ground Mount uses locally-sourced schedule 40 steel pipe (ASTM A53 Grade B) or mechanical tubing (Allied Flo-Coat, Gatorshield or Gatorshield Plus) to reduce shipping costs.

Select the steel pipe or mechanical tubing size most applicable to your application and system size. Increasing the pipe size will increase spacing between East-West piers and foundation depth.

The maximum East-West spacing is displayed on the right. Be sure to evaluate the trade-offs among fewer piers, hold depth and costs due to varying pipe or mechanical tubing sizes.

Pipe or mechanical tubing with minimum geometry and material properties of:
3” pipe: OD 3.5”, wall thickness 0.216”, 35ksi yield strength
2” pipe: OD 2.38”, wall thickness 0.154”, 35ksi yield strength
3” mechanical tubing: OD 3.5”, wall thickness 0.109”, 50ksi yield strength
2” mechanical tubing: OD 2.375”, wall thickness 0.165”, 45ksi yield strength

diagonal_Bracing.title: Diagonal Bracing
diagonal_Bracing.content: Diagonal Bracing can improve East-West pier span and reduce the total number of piers needed. It can also improve foundation depth, resulting in shallower footing.

soil_Class.title: Soil Class
soil_Class.content:
Ground Mount Design Assistant includes three different soil class options. Class 4, the default, is the most conservative soil class and is accepted by most building authorities. Choosing Class 2 or 3 may require consulting a professional engineer to verify soil bearing capacity.
Based on your selected soil class, Design Assistant calculates the minimum foundation depth required for your piers.
If you have any questions, please contact us or call 1-800-227-9523.

hole_Diameter.title: Hole Diameter
hole_Diameter.content: Increasing the foundation diameter will improve the footing depth requirement for your project.

cross_Pipes.title: Cross Pipes
cross_Pipes.content: The Cross Pipe refers to the horizontal schedule 40 or mechanical tubing that extends East-West over the vertical piers.

fx_usable_span.title: Usable Span
fx_usable_span.content: (Actual Max) The furthest span allowed as a multiple of the rafter spacing that does not exceed the Max Span

fx_max_span.title: Max Span
fx_max_span.content: Max allowable spacing between attachment points, based on engineered span charts.

fx_max_cantilever.title: Max Cantilever
fx_max_cantilever.content: Max Cantilever is calculated as 1/3 x maximum span from engineered span charts

conduit_mount.title: Conduit Mount
conduit_mount.content: Conduit Mount securely fastens conduit to the roof deck with all the proven waterproofing features of FlashFoot2. It supports ¾” or 1” EMT conduit aligning in any direction and can support other equipment such as a junction box for a versatile solution. Conduit mount is triple certified to meet structural and electrical standards under UL2239 and waterproofing standards under UL441 and TAS-100.
